qas.question: From where is the temperature of a glacier measured?
Which type of glacier is above or at freezing at it's interface and is able to slide?
What temperature makes a glacier polythermal?
What temperature determines a polar glacier?

answers.text: always below freezing point from the surface to its base

qas.question: What temperature characteristic determines a temperate glacier?

answers.text: melting point throughout the year, from its surface to its base

qas.question: What temperature is a polar glacier always above?
What temperature is a temperate glacier always above?
What two types of ice are contained in a polar glacier?

plausible_answers.text: above or at freezing at the interface

qas.question: Why are warm based glaciers not able to slide?
Why is it cold basically sure able to slide?

context: Thermally, a temperate glacier is at <a4_0><b6_0>melting point<b6_0/> throughout the year, from its surface to its base<a4_0/>. The ice of a polar glacier is <a3_0>always below <b5_0>freezing point<b5_0/> from the surface to its base<a3_0/>, although the surface snowpack may experience seasonal melting. A sub-polar glacier includes both <b7_0>temperate and polar ice<b7_0/>, depending on depth beneath the surface and position along the length of the glacier. In a similar way, the thermal regime of a glacier is often described by the temperature at its <a0_0>base alone<a0_0/>. A cold-based glacier is below freezing at the ice-ground interface, and is thus <b9_0>frozen to the underlying substrate<b9_0/>. A <a1_0>warm-based glacier<a1_0/> is <b8_0>above or at freezing at the interface<b8_0/>, and is able to slide at this contact. This contrast is thought to a large extent to govern the ability of a glacier to effectively erode its bed, as sliding ice promotes plucking at rock from the surface below. Glaciers which are <a2_0>partly cold-based and partly warm-based<a2_0/> are known as polythermal.
